text_image_relationship.layout_style: Full-page single miniature occupying the recto, surrounded by wide margins filled with scrolling acanthus foliage, grotesque drolleries and floral motifs; no accompanying text on this page

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf is reserved for halos and the frame to denote divinity; ultramarine blue highlights the Virgin’s robe signifying her importance; vermillion red appears in garments of key figures to draw attention; green and earth tones define the landscape; layered white highlights model drapery folds; the alternating warm reds and cool blues create visual balance; pigments remain vibrant with minimal oxidation.

features: Triangular arrangement of figures converging on Christ
Diagonal axis of the ladder and cross beam
Framed by a solid gold border

decorative_elements: Floral acanthus leaf border with gold bezants
Small hybrid creature flanked by red wings
Rectangular gilt frame around the scene

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill outlines in dark brown ink with varying weight for internal detail
drawing_technique.shading_method: Layered pigment application with subtle white highlighting and minimal cross-hatching
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Overlapping figures and receding hills for depth; no true vanishing point; hierarchical placement emphasizes central figures

content_theme.scene_description: This illumination depicts the Deposition from the Cross: Christ’s body is being lowered by two men—one atop a ladder supporting the left arm, another at the beam cradling the shoulders. Below, the Virgin Mary (seated left, blue mantle, hands clasped) swoons in grief, supported by St. John in a red cloak and green tunic. Mary Magdalene kneels at right in orange and red, reaching toward Christ’s feet. Joseph of Arimathea (center, yellow mantle and white cap) stands behind, holding a jar of ointment. Two angels hover in the sky—one bearing a chalice to catch the Redeemer’s blood, the other in adoration. The gold-leaf halos and INRI inscription atop the cross emphasize the theological focus. The ground plane shows green grass transitioning to rolling hills under a bright blue sky. Decorative border of intertwining acanthus leaves, flowers, and grotesques frames the scene, reinforcing its devotional function and drawing the eye inward to the central action.

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum with uniform thickness, finely pumiced and scraped to a smooth surface

notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold frame and halos
Visible underdrawing lines in brown ink under UV

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Individual noble patron for personal Book of Hours

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This miniature likely originates from a mid-15th-century French Book of Hours produced in a courtly Parisian workshop. The use of costly ultramarine and burnished gold leaf, together with the refined execution of underdrawing and gesso relief, reflects high patronage and an emphasis on personal devotional experience. The scene’s triangular composition and centralized focus on Christ echo developments in Burgundian illumination, while the rollicking border drolleries reveal influence from the Bedford or Rohan ateliers. Theologically, the Deposition underscores the human sorrow and celestial witness to Christ’s sacrifice, as indicated by the two angels collecting blood in a chalice and the jar of ointment, symbolizing anointing and redemption. Iconographically, the inclusion of Joseph of Arimathea and Nicodemus situates this biblical moment within the liturgical meditation on Holy Week rites. Thematically, the emotional interplay between Mary, John, and Mary Magdalene aligns with contemporaneous devotional literature stressing affective piety. Compared to earlier 14th-century models, this illumination demonstrates greater spatial depth and naturalism, pointing to cross-channel exchanges with the English style. Overall, the manuscript bridges traditional iconography with innovations in color layering and border grotesques, marking it as a distinctive product of mid-century Parisian illumination practice.
